description:
The fantasy world of Graxia is a shattered world of floating continents high in the sky. Each continent is connected by portals, the primary gateways between city-states that reside on these continents. Warlords command Guardians to lead armies through the portals on quests to conquer and control each other's lands.

The many continents are filled with races of all types, from Orcs, Goblins, Dwarves, Skeletons, Elves, Humans, as well as new races, such as the Celethreals and Boneshadows. While once in harmony with each other, the peace of the countryside has since been destroyed as portals open with armies pouring in from unknown continents.

What Guardians will protect your lands?

Guardians of Graxia will be released this summer as both a board game and a PC online-downloadable version. The game features dynamic strategic gameplay using more than 240 unique and spell cards, figurines, and map tiles in a fantasy-based environment. Heroes of Graxia is being released at the same time and is a Deck-Building Card Game version of the Graxia world.

Guardians of Graxia will support both single and multiplayer gameplay as well.

The Getta Goff Challenge games are a series of milk cap games (also known as Pog) with special rules and instructions meant to add a more educational twist to standard Pog.

Traditional Pog is played by stacking a variety of milk caps (aka Pogs) on top of a playing mat. Players then take turns throwing a "Slammer" (which is usually a much thicker plastic or metal Pog) onto the top of the stack in an attempt flip as many of the stacked Pogs upside down as possible. Generally, players then take  ownership of any Pogs that flipped.

In Advanced Math Getta Goff, for example, the players must carry out mathematical operations based on the instructions on the flipped Pogs.

IRONDIE uses combinations of nine different types of dice, each available in eight different colors, which allows for endless possibilities in terms of personalized sets so that you can surprise your friends with new tactics and combinations. IRONDIE dice are beautifully crafted and can also be used with existing board games, roleplaying games, or miniatures wargames.

IRONDIE dice are made of silver-plated Zamac (an alloy with a base metal of zinc and alloying elements of aluminium, magnesium and copper; the first limited edtion was made of white metal) and covered with a colored translucent paint to highlight their metal luster. Their mass is much more substantial than any plastic or resin die resulting in a better gaming feel and experience.

IRONDIE is not a difficult game, but the difference between playing and mastering it lies in the player's experience. A champion will have well-composed sets of dice and know how best to make use of them.

They said it couldn't be done.

They were right.

Nonetheless, you've been enlisted to help inventor extraordinaire Ted Alspach put the finishing touches on his Perpetual-Motion Machine. Your job is to make the machine as efficient as possible, so that you might fool the unsuspecting public long enough to make Mr. Alspach incredibly rich before he's chased out of town by a crazed mob of very cranky investors.

You're pitted against one to three other players who are also looking to get as famous as possible by riding Mr. Alspach's coattails. You'll need cunning, foresight and a bit of luck in order to beat your opponents.

Perpetual-Motion Machine is a game of set collection, skill-tree building, and long and short term strategy. Race against other players to build the most efficient machine possible using limited resources. As you build, you'll choose which areas to focus on to ensure victory.

Reimplemented by


    Kniffel: Das Kartenspiel

Mad Bishops is a two-player game which uses a 10x10 checkerboard, 25 red checkers and 25 blue checkers.  The board is initially set up as shown in the figure.

The checkers function like Chess bishops with two restrictions.  On your turn you must either kill, or move into position to kill.  If a checker is already in position to kill, it can only be used to kill. Killing is not mandatory.  I.e. if you can move an unengaged checker to engage the enemy, you can do that instead.

Mad Bishops is a game of annihilation.  I.e., you must kill all enemy checkers to win.

Colonnade is a two person game which uses a 1x8 board, 12 red checkers and 12 blue checkers.  The board is initially set up as shown in the figure.

You can pick up any one of your checkers from a stack, carrying the checkers above it along, and place it onto an adjacent stack that’s topped with a checker of your color. (A stack can be of height 1.)  Complete such a move with a discard.  I.e. if two like-colored checkers are adjacent in a stack, discard one of the two checkers.

You can also move a checker down to an unoccupied square.  You can't slide a bottom checker sideways to an unoccupied square.

The last player to have a move available wins.  I.e. if you don't have a move available on your turn, you lose.

A children's game that is not actually about the wacky adventures of the eponymous seal mascot, but a way of teaching seamanship and environmental care among other things. Players navigate the archipelago on the game board with their boats and try to land on special tiles where they can gain point tokens. Depending on the colour of the tile, this is done by answering questions, drawing pictures or giving small performances. As an added twist, only some of the point tokens actually represent real points, meaning the scores of the players are hidden until the end of the game.

With a strong will like steel Spartans responsed to the call of war:
...
"Go tell the Spartans, stranger passing by,
that here, obedient to their law, we lie."
-Simonides.
...
"During the 2nd Persian Invasion to Greece  and after the battles of Thermopylae, Artemision and Boeotia led by Xerxes himself, the Persians retreated after their first loss at the naval Battle of Salamis. Persian forces retreated to Asia and General Mardonius returned to finish what the Persian King has started. He built a fortified camp outside Plataea.

Greeks have assembled an army allied by many cities of ancient Greece. Spartans led the forces of Peloponnesos , Athenians answered the call with many other cities. It was Summer of 479 BC where the two armies has met each other opposed , even if at the Percian forces had many greek traitors  and mercenaries,  for a battle that actually ended the Persian vanquishment.

General Mardonius met his own destiny in this battle, and General Pausanias from Sparta, has archived a victory , even if their forces were outnumbered."

"Steel Will: 479 BC, The Battle of Plataea" is a history-themed wargame for two players that simulates that battle. With an abstract taste of gameplay, the core of classic historic-wargame and the feeling of a new approach at combat mechanism, we tried to create something that keeps the interest of the players alive!"

Played on a 10x10 checkered board, each player controls 6 animals of 3 different types. The Mouse can move orthogonally (horizontal or vertical) and is 'scared' of the Lion. The Lion can move diagonally (it's color locked) and is 'scared' of the Elephant. The Elephant can move both orthogonally and diagonally and is 'scared' of the Mouse; each piece can move as far as it can on its intended line of travel as long as it's not within the square perimeter (orthogonal and diagonal) of the animal its afraid of.

The goal of the game is to control 3 of the 4 'watering holes' at the end of your turn. However, if your piece is next to a piece (orthogonal AND diagonal) that it is 'scared' of it MUST move on your next turn. You cannot move a piece next to a piece (orthogonal AND diagonal) that it is 'scared' of.

Are you tired of all the SPAM emails you get on a daily basis in your inbox? Well here is your chance to spam someone else for a change.

Junk Mail is card game all about spamming other people and trying to protect yourself. You will play spam cards on your opponents and give yourself firewalls, employees and professions for protection and better chances to spam someone else. Maybe you can use a hacker or an advertising rep. to help your cause.

Learning game which can teach children to recognize sentence constituents. These are printed on little cards and can be combined in different ways. The goal is to form sentences to match the picture tiles included in the game.

EDB: Japanese Warfare was submitted for the "Dicefest Contest - A Tribute to Chessex" held in 2010.

It uses 36 dice in each players color to represent armies, units, actions, and rice production by each player.
Tokens are added to the game to enable hidden unit assignments to the armies, as well as an amount of castles and resources.

Set in feudal Japan, in the end of the Muromachi Period (1136 till 1568 A.D.) before firearms ever made it to the islands, the battles will be conducted between unit of archers, cavalry and Samurai.

EDB: Japanese Warfare is supposed to be the first of a series of games, which use a vast number of dice to represent units in battle scenarios and a simple action-point system to build and strengthen ones armies.
A souvenir of the 1939 world fair. The board reveals a miniature representation of the futuristic fair. So players could enjoy the various New York attractions in the comfort of their homes.

War has come to the ninth century as rival lords (the players) fight to conquer the land. Each player rules a fortress and the surrounding realm. Warriors are dispatched fortress and towers, crossing mountains, rivers, and open fields to engage the enemy. Using economics, diplomacy, and warfare, each player attempts to expand his realm and conquer all enemy fortresses.


     Players create a unique geography before each game begins, so it's never the same game twice.
     Antagonist is a BIG table game with marauding warriors, changing seasons, burning villages, and limitless strategies.
     Straight-forward, intuitive rules with have you playing in minutes.


(From the games label)

In The Personality Game one player askes a multiple choice question to a random player. The player asking the question gets a point for correctly predicting what that player will say about themselves. The answering player's playing piece will point in a certain direction based on his answer. That direction leads to one of four different quadrants on a board representing a personality type.  At the end of the game, the place where a player's peice ends up indicates their personality.  There are also places on the board where players get stuck unless they can get other players to guess a word on a card from that personality type.  The stuck player lists examples of the word, without saying the word itself. If they match, they can move on.  Other players gain points for matching that word. The first player to score 6 points wins.

From the back of the box: How do you play Going Ape?  By roiling the dice and collecting fruits. Different for beginners and seasoned players, beginning players collect the same fruits but seasoned  players collect every fruit. The one who collects the most fruit wins and gets a monkey in reward. The one who has the most monkeys at the end gets the main prize.

From the publisher:

"Space Frontier is a card game of space exploration. Can you colonize more planets with sufficient resources than the Invader fleet?

Choose from several different space ships to create your exploration fleet. Each ship has a different ability that is activated by discovering a planet with a specific resource type.

Once two systems have been fully explored (or the Invaders have explored one system), the game ends, and you add up the scores. If your point value is higher than the Invader's points, you win.

A variety of Invader ships let you adjust the difficulty of play, and advanced rules allow you to challenge yourself even further.

Space Frontier can be played solitaire, or with two players (head-to-head or cooperatively)."

From the publisher's website:

In the clever, creative, competitive, and captivating game of Kewbz™, opposing players compete for ownership of 'tower units' by positioning the final cube on top. Each time a corner is made, a cube is stacked at the intersection. When multiple corners are created, then multiple cubes are added into play. Clever strategy moves give you the winning edge.

From the box: Ready, set, ROLL! Land three or more marbles in a row and score!

Object: Be the first player to score 50 points. Score points by landing your marbles to create rows of three or more in the same quadrant.

User comment: The game consist of 25 marbles (5 each of 5 colors) and a circular board, about 12 inches in diameter. Around the outer rim of the board are 28  three-quarter inch holes. Between the holes and the rim of the board is where a player will roll his marble--in the style of a roulette wheel--and hope it lands in a desirable hole in a desirable quadrant of the board. Landing several marbles in a row gains points, whether they be three in a row of your color or of mixed colors.

Instructions are printed on the bottom of the box.

From the back of the box:

Everyone's a suspect when murder is on the menu. And with a Classic Detective Murder Mystery you have everything you need to serve up the perfect murder dinner party. First the invites, you choose which of your friends play which devious suspect and invite them to come along as that character. Then the shopping list, menu suggestions and recipes. Plus of course...a really tasty murder to solve. It will be drop dead fun, and by the end of the evening, one (or more) of the suspects, your 'friends', will be caught out as the murderer!

As day breaks upon Sekigahara pass, two armies stand ready to lay claim to the future of Japan. Two years before, Toyotomi Hideyoshi died leaving a son too young to rule. The council of regents sworn to defend his son split into two factions intent upon seizing power for themselves. As the fog lifts from the mountain pass, each faction stands poised for battle. Only the victor will witness the beginning of a new era in the history of Japan.

Akebono, the Japanese word meaning both “daybreak” and “beginning”, summarizes the tension and anticipation in the Sekigahara mountain pass, scene of the decisive battle of 1600 that would usher in the Edo period of Japanese history.

Akebono is a tactical dice driven game in which each player must present multiple flanks to ensure that at least some of the attacking troops will push forward. Units must be moved into a position to attack when their defeat is less likely.

In the end, the winner will be the player who best balances his aggressive and defensive tactics on the battlefield.

Description from BoardgameNews.com:

The Caméléon deck includes 54 combination cards, each with a number, a color and an object, along with a single wild chameleon card. Each player starts the round by drawing one of these cards and laying it face up on the table.

A randomly chosen dealer then turns over cards from the deck one by one, and any player who wants the card on the top of the stack must cover it with his hand, then name the three elements on the card. If he's correct, he claims the card; if he collects three cards, each with one of the three elements on his target card, he wins the round. The first player to win two rounds wins the game.

Publisher Blurb:

Looking for a spicy game to promote critical thinking? This clever new game has players frantically collecting all the ingredients for their own recipe of mild, medium or spicy guacamole! Be the first player to match 5 ingredients cards to the recipe card, and you get to keep that recipe card. Collect one of each type - mild, medium and spicy - and you win! Ole!

Game Overview:

Players are dealt five ingredient cards, which are laid face up in front of them.  The top recipe card is turned over and then players draw cards to improve their ingredients to match the recipe.  If a card is kept, another card is discarded, so that players only have five cards at a time.  Players may draw from the discard pile as well.  The first player to match the exact number of ingredients to the recipe shouts "Guacamole!" and then wins that recipe card.  The game continues until one player has won one each of the Mild, Medium and Spicy recipe cards.  The game can either be played by turns or by "scramble" (where all players draw and discard as fast as they can at the same time).

There are three special cards to spice things up: Limes - all players pass a card to their left; Salsa Bowl - all players pass a card to their right; Sombrero - all players get up and move one chair to the left, taking over another player's hand.

This is a dice-based version of the card game Clovis, which was released as a free Print and Play game early in 2009. The Dice game consists of 10 dice and a scoring sheet for each player. Players roll the dice to simulate hunting large game animals on the North American continent 12,000 years ago. There are special option dice which allow players to acquire more dice to roll and modify the results of their rolls. The game ends after the players jointly have accumulated a certain number of unsuccessful hunts (busts).

One major difference in Clovis: the Dice Game' from the original card game is the solo option. In a solo game of Clovis: the Dice Game you are challenged to earn 100 points or more to win.

Clovis: the Dice Game' Game is fast (10 - 20 minutes), easy to learn, easy to setup and put away, and best of all... FREE!!

On the board are the cards of the tarot shown. The outer circle consists of the 21 cards of the major Arcana. The inner circle is the minor arcana.

You need a Tarot deck of Rider Waite, a die, chips, pen and paper and a amulet.

Before the game begins the player ask themselves a question about his/her future. The players roll the die and move their amulet. Each card on the board contains a short oracle. Try to explain the card within your question. Some cards contain a instruction or refer to other cards. Try to fulfil the instructions or to understand (within your question) the other card.

You have to pay or receive chips depending on the card you landed with you amulet.

The game has no end. Usually, a group beforehand how long the game can last.

Ninth entry in TCS series of pnp wargames on English Civil War.
It features the battles of Adwalton Moor, Stratton and Cropredy Bridge.
It uses a chit drawing system to activate the leader, then proceeds with a simple method for resolving movement and combat, with great importance given to morale.

Each game features a single map (1A4 for Stratton and Adwalton Moor; 2A4 for Cropredy Bridge), plus 216 counters, 5 pages of rules and 2 pages of charts and tables.

Part of the English Civil War Series:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamefamily/4086/tcs-ecw-series

Each player is running their own lemonade stall.  Your goal is to try and run the stall as profitably as possible.  The game involves buying supplies to make the lemonade (cups, sugar, lemons and ice) and then selling the lemonade (hopefully for a profit).  The amount of lemonade that can be sold and the amount of profit is dependent on the weather and also on the prices charged by your competitors (the other players).  While you might sell lots of lemonade by setting a low price you won’t be making much profit!  The game takes place over a week (from Monday to Sunday).  The person who is able to run their stall the most efficiently is likely to end the game with the most money and win the game!

Not everything will always go to plan though as the weather can change, events (both good and bad) occur and special benefits can be chosen which will influence what you might do each day.

We are in Mecca, the holiest Islamic city in Saudi Arabia and prophet Muhammad's birthplace.

Year after year, Mecca receives more than a three million faithful on one of their faith's pillars: the Holy Pilgrimage or Hajj. We are going to access the inside of the Holy Mosque of Mecca right now, the main shrine of Muslim pilgrimage during the Hajj... the imposing Sacred Kaaba is just in front of us...  In order to avoid crowds during the massive influx of the faithful in the Holy Mosque the organizers have devised an innovative system to control the placement and organization of the pilgrims during their prayers to Allah.

The player who successfully introduces more pilgrims in the Holy Place according to this organization system will be the winner.


La Meca es la principal ciudad de la región del Hiyaz, en la actual Arabia Saudita, y una de las más importantes de la península de Arabia. Para los musulmanes, el peregrinaje a La Meca forma parte de uno de los aspectos fundamentales de su fe, los denominados pilares del Islam.

Cada año, cerca de tres millones de peregrinos se dirigen a la Ciudad Santa para realizar el peregrinaje mayor o Hajj durante el mes musulmán de du l-hiyya. Muchos más hacen la peregrinación menor o Umrah, que puede realizarse durante todo el año. Muy pocos no musulmanes han podido ver los ritos y rituales del Hajj, ya que está totalmente prohibida la entrada de no creyentes en La Meca. Con el fin de que no se produzcan aglomeraciones durante el Hajj, en la Mezquita Sagrada han ideado un sistema de colocación y reorganización para controlar a los peregrinos.

El jugador que consiga introducir más peregrinos en el recinto sagrado será el ganador.

User summary: A fast-play set of miniature rules for ship-to-ship combat in the Star Trek universe published in Issue 18 of Battlegames Magazine. They adapt Full Thrust to hex-play and replace damage rolls with a draw deck. Two scenarios are included with the rules.

Requirements:

Players will require these rules, several six-sided dice (d6), ship diagrams (provided), miniatures or counters representing ships, and a hex-grid. Micromachines make excellent and inexpensive miniatures in roughly 1/3700 scale.

Game Overview:

Players control 1-5 space ships and plot simultaneous turns. Movement is 2-D cinematic flight with basic momentum incorporated into the the movement mechanic. Games end when one side reaches its break point or accomplished its scenario objectives.

Combat is based on variable numbers of d6s (depending on weapon and range). When ships reach damage thresholds, players draw a card from a damage deck and apply the results (usually bad, sometimes good).

Full stats for Federation and Klingon ships as well as ship status displays are available in the magazine and on the Battlegames website: http://www.battlegames.co.uk/dispatches/dispatches_fanscifi.html .

Scoreboard Tennis is Inside Sports' latest addition to our Quick Play line of games.  All players are rated for each surface they played on, based on their real life performance.  With each season that is rated, any match-up can be replayed on your tabletop.  You can even replay entire Grand Slam tournaments.  Scoreboard Tennis offers two different quick play options.  You can choose to play a match either Set by Set or Game by Game with just a single roll of the dice determining the winner of the set or game.  Scoreboard Tennis is the perfect companion to Inside Sports' Inside Volley Tennis game.  With these two games combined, you have the option to play a match Set by Set, Game by Game, or Point by Point.  The choice is yours.  No other tennis game on the market offers this kind of versatility!

Palagonia is an alternative game played with Palago tiles, but it is not at all a variant of Palago. Palago is a two player perfect information abstract, Palagonia is a game of luck, creativity and co-operation for 3 to 5 players.

Players add tiles to a central pattern to form closed shapes which are called "creatures". The roll of the dice may cause tiles to be removed or rotated as well. When a creature is formed, the player and the previous player score points based on the size and complexity of the creature. When the tiles run out, the player with the most points wins.

Quadrat is a dice driven but strategic capturing game.
The aim of the game is to capture your oppnents pieces by building a square around them. 
Each turn you first roll a dice that indicats how many of your pieces you have to move, and how far.
After you have moved them, you check if 4 of them build a square (no matter how big). If there is a square, remove all oposing pieces inside. 
As soon as a player has only 4 or less pieces left, he loses the game.

contents:
1 board
1 dice (6-sided)
24 cubes (12 of each colour)

Advertisers variant of Snakes and Ladders, produced in 1935 to advertise D& W Gibbs "Dentifrice" Toothpaste.

Size approx.35cm X 46cm when unfolded (central fold). Printed on cardboard - board has two holes and a string at the top to allow it to be hung up as an advertising item. Rules are printed on the rear of the board.

Includes dice and 4 coloured counters.

Game was posted in a pink envelope with the rules printed on them. Publisher unknown, but game was produced for D & W Gibbs Ltd, Wapping, London E1.

The object of the game is to reach the land of Health and Happiness, and the player who gets there first wins. Along the way there are various difficulties to help and hinder the player; for example, the Gibbs Fairy helps, an Imp hinders, and a Giant (called Decay!) handicaps the player at the start of the game. Various spaces have actions associated with them, that send the player to other squares. A roll and move mechanism with a standard six sided die is used to determine each players movement.

Unusual variant of Snakes and Ladders, produced by the Gibbs toothpaste company to promote their products and raise awareness of dental hygiene. Who said that games weren't good for you?

Other links:
http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=334946

Twilight Vigilance: A chance to experience the many challenges of the Cold War while attempting to contain the spread of communism.

Solitaire game of the Cold War, using VPG's States of Siege card driven mechanics, first seen in Israeli Independence.

The player is embroiled in the Cold War and must stop the Communist overthrow of the United States. The player allocates national resources to different budgetary areas, including Military, Diplomacy, Espionage, Technology and Economy. The correct balance must be maintained in the face of different events drawn from the deck.

Geography trivia games for children. The board shows a map of the world and flags of over 50 countries. The active player gets one hint and has to correctly name the country - the hint might be a number on the world map, the flag or the capital city. When a player knows the country with one hint, he/she proceeds three fields. When two hints are necessary, one field. When three are necessary, one field. The first player to reach the finish line is the winner.
Depending on the current position, the categories can be chosen or are pre-determined. If a player cannot guess the correct country even after three hints, he/she stays in position and gets a wild card. A player with two wild cards has to discard them and gets to name a country that was already used in the game again.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

As in other Phase 10 versions, the players try to collect sets of cards in ten different phases which have to be collected in order. Only when one phase is completed, the player can start collecting the next one. 
In this board game version, players move along a circular track on the board. For this, they roll two dice and choose one of them for their movement. The field they land on contains instructions on how to draw or replace cards or even request them from others. Afterwards, phases can be laid out or added to. At the end of each player's turn, a card has to be discarded. A player who has no cards left after this moves forward two phases, the other players who have completed the current phase move forward to the next phase, all others have to try the current phase again in the next round. The first player to complete phase 10 is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

A game in the "Kleiner Rabe" (little raven) series of children's games based on the book series by author Nele Moost and illustrator Annet Rudolph.

Contents: 32 cards

The rules describe 5 variants to traditional card games:
- Alle Viere: a variant of happy families
- Gleich und Gleich: memory
- Eins, zwei, drei: a rummy variant
- Aufgepasst: a dexterity game
- Angeschmiert: a variant of old maid

From Designer: Two teams of Dwarves battle it out for control of areas. Players can use special cards that invoke the ability of the gods to attempt to gain the upper hand, but be warned! Each team has a limited supply of troops and once that supply is gone you will have no more reinforcements.

Players will engage each other in skirmish like battles to gain control over 6-7 locations. Locations are worth additional points if controlled by it's matching teams, thus the players must strategically place their units and decide when and where to attack.

To add variety there are are 30+ community cards which each player draws from to attempt to gain an advantage.

During the 8 rounds of the game players will place their units, use power ups, and attack each other. Movement of the units once placed is very limited so it is important to place the units in regard to where the player wants them to end up.

The game comes with 54 cards, instructions, and 2 dice. The game has been designed so that it is not required to reshuffle the cards except between games, ensuring that downtime is at a minimum.

From the side of the box:

"... a game of criminal pursuit, is a fast-paced, simulated street cop role-playing game that looks at the humorous side of law enforcement as it relates to the patrol division ..."

Players take turns rolling the dice and moving about the game board. Landing on various locations, players draw cards from various decks, which in turn cause good and bad events to happen. Events will cause a gain or loss in points, until one player reaches the point goal required to win the game.

From the designer's website (www.diamondbridgegame.com):

Diamond Bridge is a strategy game for two to four players. The board has a diamond-shaped grid, four corner pits and gems of two colors.

To play, take turns placing a gem on any open dot on the board.

The object of the game is to bridge sides of your color with an unbroken string of gems.

The game always results in one player completing a bridge or the other giving up. There is no deadlock.

The corner dots count for either color.

A player who spans side-to-side calls out, "Diamond Bridge!"

The game concept is basic. Players try to bridge sides of their color. It's fun to play "right out of the box." For the serious player the complexity of Diamond Bridge soon becomes apparent. Mastering the game requires a sense of balance, spatial reasoning and sustained focus.

How does this game differ from the classic earlier game Hex?
1. In Diamond Bridge, a player has only 16 pieces, and once a player has placed all their pieces, they then move an already-placed piece on their turn.
2. Diamond Bridge has no swap rule, so there is a significant first player advantage.

The game consists of 15 different murder cases which have to be solved by the players. Each case has 27 clue cards which can be acquired and either hidden or published by the player who holds them. The clues have different values, but only the player who holds a card knows that value. Each player's card rack can only hold three cards, but cards can also be swapped or stolen. At the end of each turn, a player can make a guess who the murderer is. When one player's pawn reaches a certain position on the game board, the case history is revealed and the players receive points for their guesses and their clue cards. 
Each of the 15 cases can only be played once by a given group.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

(Text extracted from the introduction of the game, written by Tony Binarelli)

"The noise of the ball that bounces on the roulette wheel. The rustle of cards that slip on the green table. The sound of dice shaken in the dice-box. The murmur of the players. The silence of expectation. The blue smoke of cigarettes. Anxiety, joy, frustration depicted by the gambling on the faces of the crowd around the tables. This is the atmosphere in the halls of a casino. A thrilling atmosphere that attracts and disrupts all your senses. An extraordinary and unrepeatable sensation that Fortune gives you when filling your pockets with money or taking away everything you have. Because, in fact, winning does not matter.  What is important is risking and defying the Fate at that beloved and, at the same time, hated green table.
The purpose of this game is just to give everyone a chance to try these feelings, tempting fate seamless. Come with me and your friends to spend an evening at this very special casino every time you want. You will not regret. Challenge your luck with roulette, poker, telesina, Macao, s1ot machines and many other exciting and funny games. If you are cautious, intelligent and, above all, lucky, you will have the chance not only to clean your playmates out, but also to break the bank of the casino and become the King of Players".

The game is composed by: 
1 - A game board with all the squares indicating the different gambling rooms: roulette, poker, Telesina, Macao, dice, Tic Tac, Black Jack, +6 / -6. Moreover there are also: the Ballroom, the Night Club, the Grill Hall and the Entrance Hall.
2 - A dice-box 
3 - Two 6-side dice
4 - Five poker dice for the Tic Tac game. 
5 - A deck of French cards used for following games: Poker - Telesina - Macao - +6 / -6. 
6 - A deck of 35 surprise cards (the "Black Jack" deck). 
7 - A slot machine. 
8 - Nr. 16 tokens with the shape of mini-bottles, different by colour, to be used to indicate the position of each player on the game board and the different bets on the roulette panel.
9 - A roulette wheel. 
10 - A lot of paper chips for the players’ stakes and to compose the bank (denominations: 5, 10, 20, 50, 100)

(Testo tratto dall'introduzione del gioco, scritta da Tony Binarelli)
"ll rumore della pallina che saltella sulla ruota della roulette.
ll fruscio delle carte da gioco che scivolano sul tavolo verde. Il suono dei dadi agitati nel bicchiere. Il mormorio dei giocatori. Il silenzio dell’attesa. Il fumo azzurro delle sigarette. L’ansia, la gioia, la frustrazione che il gioco dipinge sui volti della folla attorno ai tavoli. L’atmosfera che si respira nelle sale di un casinò è questa. Un’atmosfera da brivido che seduce e sconvolge tutti i tuoi sensi. Sensazione straordinaria e irrepetibile che ti dà la
fortuna quando riempie le tue tasche di soldi, oppure ti toglie
tutto ciò che possiedi. Perché, in realtà, vincere non importa.
Ciò che conta è rischiare, sfidando la sorte a quell’amato e
allo stesso tempo odiato tavolo verde. Lo scopo di questo gioco è proprio quello di dare a tutti la possibilità di provare queste sensazioni, di sfidare la sorte senza soluzione di continuità. Vieni insieme a me ed ai tuoi amici a trascorrere una serata in questo casinò molto speciale ogni volta che vuoi. Non te ne pentirai. Sfida la fortuna alla roulette, a poker, a telesina, a macao, alla s1ot machine e a tanti altri giochi esaltanti e divertenti. Se sarai accorto, intelligente e soprattutto fortunato non solo avrai la possibilità di sbancare i tuoi compagni di gioco, ma anche di far «saltare il banco» dello stesso casinò e di trasformarti quindi nel Re dei Giocatori".

Il gioco si compone di:
1 - Un tabellone contenente tutte le caselle indicanti le varie
sale da gioco: Roulette, Poker, Telesina, Macao, dadi, Tic Tac, Black Jack, +6/-6, inoltre vi sono il Salone delle Feste - Il Night Club - il Grill e la casella Ingresso.
2 - Un bussolotto per giocare con i dadi
3 - Due dadi numerati.
4 - 5 dadi con i simboli delle carte per il Tic Tac.
5 - Un mazzo di carte francesi che viene utilizzato per i
seguenti giochi: Poker - Telesina - Macao - +6/-6.
6 - Un mazzo di 35 carte sorpresa (mazzo" Black Jack").
7 - Una slot machine.
8 - 16 segnalini a forma di mini-bottiglie, ognuno di diverso
colore, per segnalarci movimenti di ciascun giocatore sulla
tavola da gioco. Le bottiglie sono di diversa forma, ma abbinate dallo stesso colore.
9 - Una roulette.
10 - La riproduzione di fiches per la composizione delle poste
dei singoli giocatori e per la dotazione del banco. Nei seguenti tagli: 5, 10, 20, 50, 100.

Since ancient times along the Nile, the Eye, Scarab and Snake vie for positional advantage.   Yet, they are not completely in control of their movements.  Through clever maneuvering of your own tokens and those of your opponents, be the first to reach your home base in the sands of Egypt.  But beware, sandstorms can literally change your world.

Each player has 8 tokens and one home base.   Players roll 4 tokens and move 4 tokens, including their own and those of their opponents in order to get their tokens home first.  But even the best laid plans can be upended  when a player rolls a “sandstorm”.

This is an abstract game of simple rules and greater depth than one might expect at first glance.   Elements of many classic designs are echoed here, the result is a fresh synthesis of luck, maneuver and skill.  It’s one of the very few abstract games that works equally well with two or three players.

In this Decktet trick-taking game, you're a hermit who tries to avoid having people follow you home. So are all of your opponents.

The daily life of the hermits is represented by tricks of cards, and there will typically be more than one trick in play at a time. The goal is to avoid taking tricks with personality cards in them. Tricks that don't have personalities in them don't matter one way or the other.

The above description is from the Decktet Book, where the game first appeared.

Hermit is a game akin to Hearts where players are attempting to avoid taking cards that are worth points. Rather than a single suit being avoided, Hermit requires that you do not win tricks which contain "personality" cards, one of the three sub-types of cards in the Decktet, which represent a person following you home and thus ruining your perfect life of solitude.

Regardless of the number of players, tricks are played open to the table. On a player's turn they must add a card from their hand to a trick with the requirement that the card being played shares at least one suit with the last played card on that trick. If they cannot meet that requirement they must use a card to start a new trick. If the card they play is the highest rank in the trick the entire trick moves in front of them. Thus any new tricks always start in front of the player opening them.

When a fourth card is added to a trick it is "closed" and the cards are captured by whomever the trick is in front of. If on a player's turn there are no available tricks, including the first turn of the game, each player simultaneously starts a new trick and that player then takes their turn, in effect allowing them to play two cards in a row. When the last player places their last card any unclosed tricks are discarded and each personality card taken counts its rank for scoring with Crowns being rank 10.

When one player reaches a predetermined score, typically 66 or 100, or a certain number of deals are completed the game is over and the player with the fewest points is the loneliest and thus the winner.

Special rules exist regarding Aces and Crowns as well as a Shoot the Moons/Suns variant, a "House Party" variant, and rules for 2-player Hermit games which incorporates a "Cottage" and laying off throughout the game.

Backwards up the mossy glen
Turned and trooped the goblin men
With their shrill repeated cry,
"Come buy, come buy."

Dealing with goblins is always a struggle with temptation, leading through in the loss of innocence, ultimately revealing the power of sisterhood. Yet goblins are oblivious to symbolism. For them, it is just a matter of economics.

This Decktet game, inspired by Christina Rossetti's poem of the same name, is a series of auctions in which players buy cards on the goblins' terms: They'll give you coins for nothing, until you've won some auctions --- but later, your only way to get more coins will be from your fellow players.

This description is adapted from the Decktet Book, where the game first appeared.

Rules: Decktet Wiki

In Campaign, you are the leader of a political party. Goal is to maximize seats to win the elections.

After you and your teammates each have compiled a directory of candidates, the election campaign begins. At your turn, you can manipulate the news, political opponents bottom out if your reputation polish.

During the game, controlling political topics the news. A theme in the news, determine if your candidates are worth seats. All political candidates have two faces: the face and the true face. A candidate is always in the face of politics. But reputations can be damaged. Your teammates can throw mud, and if your candidate harm so they pose no more seats.

In the deck there are events, including polls. During a poll the players count their seats. Who is currently the largest party is given an additional seat. The winner of the poll can increase their own advantage so.

The game ends when a player can't draw a card.

Geth20 Game is a new ’serious’ mobile game about Peace Building. It is specifically developed for Kenyan youth, to enhance understanding of the basic dynamics of conflict, conflict escalation, the role of the community and the role of individuals in preventing conflict and promoting peace.

Game scenario
You find yourself in the slums of Nairobi, your aim is to survive and build houses for you and your extended family. You have to build a certain amount of houses per level to win the game. Remember to keep the community bar in the green too! otherwise you still can’t win. Drought, crime and corruption are rife.

This game was initially intended to be an expansion to Avalon Hill's Caesar's Legions. It has turned into much more than that. It has so many distinct features to it, the only recognizable part that remains are the counters. Caesar's Legions was a captivating game and pretty successful for Avalon Hill. It broke the mold of their traditional WWII games and the traditional combat chart that they used. There were two short comings with the game - there were only five scenarios, and there was no campaign game.

Caesar in Gaul covers a much shorter time period, which makes a campaign game more adaptable. At present it has nine historical scenarios. The rules are more complex as is the combat system, but it remains an intermediate level game, and is highly suited for solitaire play. It has become the sequel game that Caesar's Legions players have always wanted.

The second Edition rules are released and address all of the criticisms presented to date. They are a free download PDF as well as other charts used in the game.

A computer game for the 4th scenario - Crassus in Aquitania is also available. It gives players a feel for the game mechanics. Useful to play before diving into the scenarios or campaign game.

Some players have mentioned their hesitance to purchase a board game with a lot of cards in it. The 78 tribal cards are for player reference. It makes locating the various tribes on the board easier, gets you more familiar with the strange tribal names, and instantly identifies resources and leaders available for that tribe. Also useful for random selections when called for, and organizing initial tribal morale in the campaign game set up.

The object of the game
Players must correctly answer questions in each of the game's catagories and complete the circuit of the board. Once all four catagory victims have been obtained by any player, the play proceeds to the Trauma Center, in the middle of the board, for the game's winning question. each player must proceed to the Trauma Center, up the original Star-branch from which he began.

Designed for everyone in the medical field! Paramedics, EMT's, Doctors, Nurses and AFA's.

From the box back:

Learn about time as you help your mouse climb to the top fo the clock.

Aim of the game:
To correctly match the activity cards with the clock and reach the top of the clock first.

Contents:
1 Clock playing board
2 Clock hands and pivot
16 Illustrated activity cards
18 Clock cards
4 Mice and plastic stands

Aim of the game
To correctly match the activity cards with the clock cards and reach the top of the clock first.

How to play
1. The hands are attached to the clock face.  The playing board is assembled and placed in the centre of the table.

2. Four activity cards are dealt to each player, picture side up.  Any leftover cards are discarded, along with the matching clock cards.  The remaining clock cards are spread out face down on the table.

3. Each player chooses a mouse counter and places it in the 'start' area of the playing board.

4. The first player begins by turning over one of the clock cards on the table.  They read aloud the time and look to see if it matchs the time on one of their activity cards.  If a match is made, they move the clock hands on the playing board to the correct time, move their mouse forward one space and keep the clock card.

5. If the time on the clock card does not match any of the player's activity cards, the clock card is returned to the table, face down, and play moves onto the next player.

6. If the clock card shows 'one o'clock', each player must move their mouse back one space on the clock board.  All players also return one of their clock cards to the table.  The matching activity card is then back in play.

7.  Play continues until one player has matched all their cards and has reached the top of the clock playing board.

Winning the game
The first player to have match all their activity cards with the clock cards and reached the last space at the top of the clock playing board is the winner.

"Las Torres de Zoraida" (Zoraida´s Towers) is a game based on the legend of the construction of Mudejar towers of San Martin and San Salvador in Teruel.
Players build a tower against a virtual constructor, but only contribute to more wins.
Using different profession of the medieval epoch, up to constructing the tower completely, Depending on the professions not chosen by the players, the builder vrtual opponent will construct more or less floors, and if his tower ends before that the players, all lose 
In the version for two players compete against each one.
The game was a finalist in the second game creation contest "Ciutat de Granollers" in 2008

In the Trenches: Through Mud and Blood is the third game of the In the Trenches series. Designed by John Gorkowski, this series enables players to game historically accurate simulations of tactical operations from the Great War. ITT challenges players to move and fight with company-level formations made of separate platoon-sized units during five minute, impulsed-based turns. The historically accurate maps are scaled to 100 yards per hex. This approach recreates WWI command and control problems and inspire historically accurate play without forcing decisions.

In the Trenches: Through Mud and Blood includes seven operations. "Balkan Brawl" takes place in Macedonia, "Schneiders at Juvincourt" pits French tanks against German infantry, "The Lost Battalion" and "Go to Hell!" depict the battles of the 308th US Infantry Battalion in the Charlevaux Valley, "War of Machines" and "Combined Arms" involves British and German tanks on the Western Front, and "Kaiserschlacht" depicts trench fighting between the British and Germans during the last German offensive of the First World War.

Included in In the Trenches: Through Mud and Blood are five 11.5" x 8" maps, 264 die-cut counters, one rulebook, guides for all seven operations, one reference card, and two D6s.

(source: Grenier Games website)


Maps:

Maps are single-sheet 11.5" x 8" and printed on stiff, glossy cardstock.

The featured five maps are:
"Hill 06" covers a piece of territory near Lake Doiran in Macedonia
"Juvincourt" features the village of that name, and the nearby countryside 
"Charlevaux Valley" contains the battlefield of the Lost Battalion, 
"Open Ground" leaves a clean playing field for the tanks (and perfect for make-your-own battles),
"Racecourse Redoubt" features a network of trenches on the Western Front.

Scenarios:

Balkan Brawl
To break the stalemate at Salonika, the Allies planned to strike the Bulgarian centre. As part of a larger effort, the 11th Worcestershire Battalion, 78th Brigade, 22nd Division aimed to capture "06", a strongpoint of the Bulgarian 9th Division on "Pip Ridge" just east of Lake Doiran in Macedonia. At 2145, after days of intermittent shelling, the preparatory barrage ceased and the officers' shrill whistles rose from the din. British troops filtered down into Hana Ravine just before bounding up the slope to "06".

Schneiders at Juvincourt
As part of the Nivelle Offensive, Commandant Louis Bossut led five "Special Artillery" groups of 16 Schneider tanks each into German lines near Berry-Au-Bac at 0600. Groupment Bossut crossed the first German trench line with infantry against light resistance. But nagging artillery fires and mechanical failures began to nibble away at his force. Four kilometers later, Bossut swung northward to cross the second German trench line with his 60 remaining tanks and the 151st Infantry Regiment. After crossing around 0900, Bossut split his force sending two groups north toward Juvincourt, two more west toward Mauchamp and one south toward the Aisne.

The Lost Battalion
On 2 October 1918, elements of the U.S. 77th "Liberty" Division from New York attacked north into the Argonne Forest. Major Whittlesey's force of two battalions from the 308th Infantry and two platoons of the 306th Machine Gun outpaced neighboring American units by penetrating a full kilometer into German lines. At dusk, Whittlesey's men dug in along the north slope of a valley between a road at the top and a stream at the bottom. Company K of the 307th joined the following morning. Seeing that this force had outpaced its flank protection, the Germans slowly encircled the "Lost Battalion", in a pocket about 500 meters east of Moulin de Charlevaux. At 3 PM on October 3, the Germans launched their first attack.

Go to Hell!
After 5 days of siege, the Lost Battalion was out of bandages, drinking from the Charlevaux Brook, and coughing on the stench of the rotting corpses that surrounded them. the Germans sent an American POW back to his comrades with a letter offering to accept an American surrender. According to legend, Major Whittlesey spat back, "Go to Hell!"

Kaiserschlacht
The Kaiser's Battle began at 0435 with an unprecedented artillery bombardment of gas, smoke and high explosive rounds. About 9,955 tubes of all sizes rained over 1,100,000 shells across 40 miles of frontage. At 0940 the firing stopped; Stosstruppen immediately sprang from their shell holes as German regulars emerged from trenches close behind. Near Grugies not far from St. Quentin, Germany's 238th division slammed into Britain's 36th Ulster amid dense fog and lingering smoke. The recently arrived Ulster men had just taken over French positions and had yet to fully implement the new defense in depth doctrine.

War of Machines
During the Second Battle of Cambrai, British troops of Byng's third Army broke through the Hindenburg Line to "the green fields beyond." Leading the way, tanks of the 12th Battalion helped XVII Corps capture Niergnies. Just east of the town, Captain Roe's tank, L16, paused at Mont Neuve Farm. there he spotted four MIVs coming his way from the east. C Company - he thought.

Combined Arms
After Ludendorff's Operation Georgette bogged down in the north, he made a thrust for Amiens. At dawn on April 24th, thirteen German tanks lumbered forward over a gloomy moonscape with infantry close behind. After plowing through Britain's 173rd Brigade, they covered 4,000 yards to reach the Cachy Switch Line, a stitch work arrangement of incomplete trenches between Villers Bretonneux and Cachy. At about that time, Captain Brown led three Mark IVs to the Cachy Switch Line with orders to hold at all costs.

(source: user's description)

Anzio / Cassino is the first pair of games in Mike Rinella's Battle Command Series with Worthington Games.

The Battle Command Series are quick playing games with large 7/8" counters, a double sided map board, rules, and dice. Each battle has 4 pages of rules. Units are rated for their strength and movement, as well an endurance rating that reflect how much damage a unit can sustain in combat. Each battle includes 2 scenario's, one for the complete campaign, and one for a shorter scenario. In Anzio for example you get a scenario starting with Operation Shingle running from January 22 to February 20, 1944. Each turn represents five days of combat, and each hex is about 2 miles across.

Octagons is an abstract boardgame from the family of connection games. The rules as given in New Rules for Classic Games are: The game uses an Archimedean grid with halved octagons (resulting in irregular hexagons). Both players take turns making moves. On his turn, a player can either fill in one half of an octagon or two squares.

The first move can be swapped by the pie rule. The player who forms an unbroken connection between the edges of his colour wins. Draws are not possible.

A very old pair of games (1930s?) in German.  Himmel und Erde is a chutes and ladders type game where players travel from Spring through Christmas by either going on the Earth or through Heaven.  The description on the box cover states "Das lustige Wurfelspiel der bunten Welt im Jarheslauf".

Die Tierschau has pictures of animals with a pair of dice with different totals on a board.  The players apparently work their way across the board by advancing a pawn from animal to animal along the way.  There are four different sets of rules, for shorter, longer and "Doppelspiel", or "double play".  The box top describes the game as "Im Spiel kreuz und quer durch das Tierreich".
